author: Lucille Keen
title: Kathy Jackson misused union funds, ordered to repay $1.4m
text:
Publicly supported and legally represented his partner: Michael Lawler and HSU's Kathy Jackson. Supplied. by Lucille Keen Whistleblower and former head of the Health Services Union Kathy Jackson has been found to have misused union funds and ordered to repay $1.4 million to the union.
Federal Court Justice Richard Tracey found Ms Jackson improperly used her position as head of the union to gain advantage for herself.
Justice Tracey ordered Ms Jackson pay the union $1,338,626.16 in compensation for damage to the union as a result of contravening the Fair Work Registered Organisations Act.
She has also been ordered to repay $67,912 of overpaid salary that she received while on holidays.
Kathy Jackson at her wombarra house. Louise Kennerley Ms Jackson was accused of misusing $1.4 million in union funds on shopping trips, divorce payments and holidays.
Ms Jackson declared bankruptcy on the first day of the trial and did not defend the case but has denied any wrongdoing .
During the trial, in early July, the court heard Ms Jackson established a "secret" slush fund, under the name of the National Health Development Account, using a $250,000 payment from a Melbourne cancer hospital for members' back pay.
Counsel for the Health Services Union, Mark Irving, SC, said she "set up a scheme to circumvent" having to declare the money and her spending, to the union.
 "She wants to keep secret what she is doing. The purpose of setting up these arrangements is to avoid disclosure requirements."
Mr Irving said the account was opened and used by Ms Jackson and was never audited by the union or taken into account for the union's finances.
The HSU has sought $2.5 million from Ms Jackson.
The trustee of Ms Jackson's estate said they would not fight the case and the union decided to proceed despite not being able to reap financial benefits if they succeeded.
The court was told Ms Jackson withdrew large sums of money, up to $9,800 at a time in the days before 14 holidays to places such as Hong Kong, London and Los Angeles.
It was also told she spent $3000 on Bulgari luxury goods, a $4000 portrait by renowned artist Charles Blackman and more than $2000 on a dinner at celebrity chef George Calombaris' restaurant The Press Club.
The union also claimed Ms Jackson transferred $102,000 to her former husband Jeff Jackson between March 2008 and March 2010.
Ms Jackson has claimed she was allowed to use $4,000 from the NHDA for personal expenditure.
"We say she invented the $4000 allowance," Mr Irving said.
